pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw:
![random_walk.png](data/bitbucket.org/repo/jgXqbo/images/529147437-random_walk.png)


```
#!xml

      <sensor name="imu_sensor" type="imu">
        <pose>0 0 0 3.141593 0 0</pose>
        <always_on>1</always_on>
        <update_rate>1000.0</update_rate>
		<imu>
			<angular_velocity>
				<x>
					<noise type="gaussian">
						<mean>0</mean>
						<density>0.0</density>
						<bias_mean>0.0</bias_mean>
						<bias_stddev>0.0</bias_stddev>
						<walk_density>0.1</walk_density>
						<walk_correlation_time>10</walk_correlation_time>
					</noise>
				</x>
			</angular_velocity>
		</imu>
      </sensor>

```


# Design

* I'm passing dt into the noise Apply method. This is flexible and allows the calling method to keep track of the time since the last call.
* I decided to extend the existing Gaussian noise class while keeping backwards compatibility with existing sdf models.
* For more accurate noise simulation it makes sense to specify noise density instead of std. dev, but for backwards compatibility I allow specifying either one, but not both.  std. dev. = sqrt(noise density / sampling time)

# Tasks
* Extend GaussianNoise class to support bias random walk and noise density  (DONE)
* sdformat update for new noise params: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/329 (DONE)
* Add an integration test to check the random walk behavior (DONE)
* Unit tests (DONE) (all pass)
* style, total errors found: 0 (DONE)

# Questions
* branch: I based this on gazebo8. This doesn't break API, just extends sdf. Was this the best choice?
* sdformat version: How do I set the CI server to use the new sdformat?
content.html:
<sensor name="imu_sensor" type="imu">
        <pose>0 0 0 3.141593 0 0</pose>
        <always_on>1</always_on>
        <update_rate>1000.0</update_rate>
        <imu>
            <angular_velocity>
                <x>
                    <noise type="gaussian">
                        <mean>0</mean>
                        <density>0.0</density>
                        <bias_mean>0.0</bias_mean>
                        <bias_stddev>0.0</bias_stddev>
                        <walk_density>0.1</walk_density>
                        <walk_correlation_time>10</walk_correlation_time>
                    </noise>
                </x>
            </angular_velocity>
        </imu>
      </sensor>

Design

  • I'm passing dt into the noise Apply method. This is flexible and allows the calling method to keep track of the time since the last call.
  • I decided to extend the existing Gaussian noise class while keeping backwards compatibility with existing sdf models.
  • For more accurate noise simulation it makes sense to specify noise density instead of std. dev, but for backwards compatibility I allow specifying either one, but not both. std. dev. = sqrt(noise density / sampling time)

Tasks

  • Extend GaussianNoise class to support bias random walk and noise density (DONE)
  • sdformat update for new noise params: https://bitbucket.org/osrf/sdformat/pull-requests/329 (DONE)
  • Add an integration test to check the random walk behavior (DONE)
  • Unit tests (DONE) (all pass)
  • style, total errors found: 0 (DONE)

Questions

  • branch: I based this on gazebo8. This doesn't break API, just extends sdf. Was this the best choice?
  • sdformat version: How do I set the CI server to use the new sdformat?

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw:
Hi @jgoppert 

Firstly, this looks like a really impressive effort and I agree with the general approach you have taken (passing a measurement of elapsed time into the ```Apply``` method was the approach I took when I started working on this issue a year or two ago). I'm sorry that it's taken so long to get some feedback from any of your assigned reviewers. I'm sure, like me, the others are plagued by work right now. To be frank, it's been a while since I worked with Gazebo and I'd need to check-out the repo again to test the fix, which might take a while. @nkoenig or @scpeters are probably better folk to action this review.

While we're modifying the ```Apply``` method, we should have a high-level brainstorm think as to whether we should also consider spatially-correlated error. For example, in WiFi localization RSSI and ToF are perturbed by environmental clutter. The problem is similar for GNSS, temperature, etc. I'm not suggesting that we add a distribution that accounts for spatially-correlated noise, but merely that the NoisePlugin could have access to the current position of the sensing element (phase center of antenna, temperature sensor). 

It would only really make sense to pass in an absolute position, not delta position to make this happen. Should we not also consider passing a global time rather than delta time, and have the noise model track the delta internally?

I apologize that these thoughts aren't very specific right now. It;s been a while since I've thought about this!

Andrew
content.html:
Hi @jgoppert

Firstly, this looks like a really impressive effort and I agree with the general approach you have taken (passing a measurement of elapsed time into the Apply method was the approach I took when I started working on this issue a year or two ago). I'm sorry that it's taken so long to get some feedback from any of your assigned reviewers. I'm sure, like me, the others are plagued by work right now. To be frank, it's been a while since I worked with Gazebo and I'd need to check-out the repo again to test the fix, which might take a while. @nkoenig or @scpeters are probably better folk to action this review.

While we're modifying the Apply method, we should have a high-level brainstorm think as to whether we should also consider spatially-correlated error. For example, in WiFi localization RSSI and ToF are perturbed by environmental clutter. The problem is similar for GNSS, temperature, etc. I'm not suggesting that we add a distribution that accounts for spatially-correlated noise, but merely that the NoisePlugin could have access to the current position of the sensing element (phase center of antenna, temperature sensor).

It would only really make sense to pass in an absolute position, not delta position to make this happen. Should we not also consider passing a global time rather than delta time, and have the noise model track the delta internally?

I apologize that these thoughts aren't very specific right now. It;s been a while since I've thought about this!

Andrew

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.html:
@asymingt Thanks for the input. I agree that it would be beneficial if noise models had access to more data. One thing limiting this is that the wind plugin is now using the noise as well. For the wind plugin there is no sensor or position that could be passed in. So we would have to be able to handle that edge case. My first inclination was to pass the sensor pointer to the noise ctor, but this stopped me from doing that. Any thoughts on how to get around this?

Another case related to your suggestions is table/polynomial based bias. I have an application where I have a mapped a magnetic field indoors and would like to use my polynomial, heading(X, Y, Z) model for magnetometer bias. I'm not sure if this fits here but I would like to think about how to plug it in long term.

Regarding absolute time vs time delta, I think it would be more flexible if we passed absolute time in. It is a bit more information the user could use for the noise model. They could have t as well as dt at their disposal.

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw: @nkoenig @asymingt @hsu @scpeters I don't want this to bit rot, so how best to proceed. I was thinking about just updating it from time delta to taking an absolute time. Would be in a good place to merge it then? Implementing the position correlated noise seems to warrant more thought and a separate PR.
content.html: @nkoenig @asymingt @hsu @scpeters I don't want this to bit rot, so how best to proceed. I was thinking about just updating it from time delta to taking an absolute time. Would be in a good place to merge it then? Implementing the position correlated noise seems to warrant more thought and a separate PR.

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw:
My apologies for such a long time in reviewing this. I agree that considering position correlation will probably require a bit more thought.

I need to think a little more about the distinction between absolute time and delta time. One tricky situation there is what to do when the simulation time is reset.
content.html:
My apologies for such a long time in reviewing this. I agree that considering position correlation will probably require a bit more thought.

I need to think a little more about the distinction between absolute time and delta time. One tricky situation there is what to do when the simulation time is reset.

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw: Might it be easier to construct the base ```Noise``` class with a ```SensorPtr``` and provide protected functions on the ```Noise``` class to grab the absolution time and absolution sensor position in the world frame. These functions would typically be called by user code within the ```Noise::Apply``` function.  It will then be up to the sensor noise model itself to track the delta time or position and calculate the correct perturbation. The advantage of this approach is that there is no change to the existing ```Apply(...)``` signature, as we're augmenting the base ```Noise``` class with additional (optional) information.
content.html: Might it be easier to construct the base Noise class with a SensorPtr and provide protected functions on the Noise class to grab the absolution time and absolution sensor position in the world frame. These functions would typically be called by user code within the Noise::Apply function. It will then be up to the sensor noise model itself to track the delta time or position and calculate the correct perturbation. The advantage of this approach is that there is no change to the existing Apply(...) signature, as we're augmenting the base Noise class with additional (optional) information.

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw:
I think that would work. We are currently discussing design ideas for sensors in the following document:

* https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/11599873/Ignition+Sensors

I'll make sure to put a reference to this discussion there in case this doesn't get merged.
content.html:
I think that would work. We are currently discussing design ideas for sensors in the following document:

  • https://osrfoundation.atlassian.net/wiki/spaces/GAZ/pages/11599873/Ignition+Sensors

I'll make sure to put a reference to this discussion there in case this doesn't get merged.

pullrequest.title: Add random walk support to GaussianNoise

content.raw:
Assertions only print out an error message in production. This could lead to division by zero.

You could change the assert to an `if`, where the `else` clause falls back to `this->GetStdDev`.
content.html:
Assertions only print out an error message in production. This could lead to division by zero.

You could change the assert to an if, where the else clause falls back to this->GetStdDev.
